journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Fatigue life and reliability evaluation for dental implants based on computer simulation and limited test data

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, De-Lin Institute of Technology, Taiwan, ROC
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Central University, Taiwan, ROC
3Department of Art & Plastic Design, National Taipei University of Education, Taiwan, ROC

author-notes.corresp: Yuo-Tern Tsai, Department of Mechanical Engineering, De-Lin Institute of Technology, 1, Lane 380, Ching Yun Road, Tucheng, Taipei, Taiwan 236, ROC. Email: yttsai@dlit.edu.tw

abstract.p: Dental implants have been extensively utilized on edentulous patients for many years. The fatigue life of dental implants is critical for them being approved to use in human body because they are within the area of biomedicine. To perform a preliminary investigation of fatigue life of dental implants, this article reports a method of fatigue life estimation based on the combination of computer simulation and limited test data. The method is developed based on a probabilistic form of fatigue life given according to the properties of material fatigue strength. The procedure is carried out by shifting of the regression line (representing the fatigue–life curve) to the desired value of the probability of occurrence. Computer simulation includes both stress analysis and life estimation which are done using the ANSYS software. This estimation model offers a method for fatigue life evaluation and yields the life distribution in respect to the scatter of the cyclic properties of dental implants. Furthermore, the reliability of lifetime is calculated based on the probabilistic form. The purposes of this study are to predict fatigue life using a small amount of testing data and to provide a risk assessment for dental implants in use.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: It is essential to ensure that the strength of a design is endowed with sufficient resistance against failure. It is not always possible to alter the operational loading to suit the design concept since the loading is governed by the operational conditions. To satisfy the operational conditions, a design is often modified either through improving materials strength or redesigning the geometric structure. Considering the random characteristics of material strength, reliability becomes an important issue in design processes. To develop availability sound designs, Tsai1 presented a method of evaluating reliability and maintainability in early design phase. The often used method in fulfilling reliability design is by integrating optimization techniques to obtain the satisfactory solutions.2,3

Focusing on operational life of a design, fatigue problem is the critical issue because most of the failures corresponding to time belong to this type.4 The fatigue life of a design can be estimated based on the S–N curve of materials describing the relationship between the cyclic loads and the lifetime. Generally, the life characteristic curve can be obtained by curve fitting for the experimental data. Considering the random properties of material strength and loading, the experimental data can be expressed as a probabilistic form. The probabilistic form plays a crucial role in design enhancement because the magnitude of the scatter could significantly affect the fatigue life and consequently the reliable operation for a design.5 Based on the probabilistic form, the reliabilities with respect to time can be further calculated so that a risk assessment for fatigue failure can then be offered during usage. Several typical studies about probabilistic form of fatigue life, for example, Anoop et al.6 proposed a method in determining the probability distribution of fatigue life using the Monte Carlo simulation technique for estimating the fatigue life. Thies et al.7 reported an approach by combining experimental tank test data with numerical modeling to identify maximum load points and quantify the fatigue life.

Dental implants (DIs) are extensively used as an alternative for edentulous patients. In addition to the stability of implants, aesthetics are another important issue. Most DIs are manufactured using pure titanium through a series of manufacturing processes such as lathing, milling, punching and thread-cutting, etc.8 There are many failures that have occurred while using DIs in human body, such as cracking of ceramic crowns, bone loss at the root of a dental implant and fatigue failure of DIs, etc. The failures and the complications that possibly occur when using DIs to support restorations have been reported in Chee and Jivraj.9 Aiming to brittle crown failure, Qasim et al.10 studied the effects of superposed tangential force by off-axis indentation loading on curved bi-layers consisting of brittle shells filled with polymer support material. Finite element analysis was used to determine the basic stress states within the dome structures, and to confirm a shift in maximum tensile stress from the near-contact area to the dome sides.11 Moreover, crested bone loss may result in the failure of DIs, bone remodeling would be the physiological process through which bone adapts itself to the mechanical environment.12 In this article, the fatigue failure of DIs is analyzed to perform a preliminary investigation of fatigue life in dynamic testing. A life estimation model expressed with probabilistic form is developed based on the combination of computer simulation and a small amount of test data. Computer simulation is to establish the weak points of geometry structure and predict the failure time of DIs. The simulation results are further combined with the test data to construct the estimation model of fatigue life for DIs.

The CAD models of the DIs are constructed according to the geometry shape and dimensions of a DI offered by a dental clinic which is specialized in DIs manufacturing.13 The ANSYS software is used as a tool to analyze the stress distribution and the related lifetime characteristics.14 The possible fracture points of the DIs are determined according to the results of stress analysis. The fatigue lifetime of the corresponding component is further investigated including the safety factors and the sensitivity of the lifetimes to the loads. The estimated lifetimes under different fatigue theories including Soderberg, Goodman and Gerber models are compared with the experimental results to determine the most appropriate model used in lifetime prediction.15 The parameters of the life estimation model are estimated using regression analysis method based on the combined data obtained through computer simulation and fatigue testing. The estimated values of the mean and the standard deviation of the fatigue life based on the proposed model are used to calculate the reliability of fatigue life. The purposes of the study are to provide a preliminary investigation of fatigue life for DIs as well as operational reliability evaluation before progressing fatigue testing based on the proposed life estimation model.

sec.title: Probabilistic form of fatigue life
sec.p: To calculate the fatigue life of a design, the behavioral characteristics of the material under cyclic loading need to be investigated. The fatigue life of a design is generally estimated based on the concepts of local stress and strain. The fatigue life curve representing material characteristics can be expressed with the equation proposed by Morrow16 as (1)ɛa=σf'E(2Nf)b+ɛf'(2Nf)c. The equation is the summation of two separate curves for elastic strain–amplitude life (ɛae-2Nf) and for plastic strain–amplitude life (ɛap-2Nf). The parameter ɛa is the total strain amplitude, Nf is the number of cycles to fatigue failure, σf' is the fatigue strength coefficient, b is the fatigue strength exponent, ɛf' is the fatigue ductility coefficient and c is the fatigue ductility exponent.

The parameters σf',b,ɛf',c represent the cyclic properties of a material, which are usually determined using a linear regression method based on the experimental dependence Nf=f(σa) and Nf=f(ɛa). Actually, the material properties are random in nature. The degree of this randomness is given by the magnitude of the scatter of the experimental points along the regression line, representing the fatigue–life curve of the material. Generally, the values, σf',b,ɛf',c obtained through regression analysis are corresponding to a 50% probability of occurrence.17

However, the computational estimations of fatigue damage, obtained by solely employing the parameters of the regression line, could be overestimated or underestimated depending upon the mutual positions of the regression line and the experimental data. The calculation of the fatigue damage of a material should be interpreted with probabilistic forms. Using this approach to determine the parameters, the fatigue life of a design can be expressed as a distribution incorporating the scatter of the material’s cyclic properties.

The low stress cycle fatigue is considered for DIs testing since the acted loads are within the yielding point. As a result, the Basquin’s equation is adopted and the elastic strain–amplitude life is expressed with the form.18 (2)σa=σf'(2Nf)b, where σa is the stress amplitude. Considering the experimental points (σai,2Nfi), the scheme for determination of the regression line of the P (%) probability of occurrence is shown in Figure 1. Here, RL (50%) is the regression line; RL (1%) is the regression line shifted to the value of P = 1%; sN is the standard deviation of the distribution; d (1%) indicates multiples of standard deviation determining the value of P = 1%; PDF is the probability density function (log-normal distribution of Nf).19 Figure 1.
Scheme for determination of the regression line for P(%) probability of occurrence.

While using this model, several assumptions are made as follows:
the lifetime (that is the number of cycles to fatigue failure Nf on a harmonic cycle load of amplitude, σa) has a log-normal distribution;
the scatter of the lifetimes at various stress levels is equivalent; and
the values of the material constants (σf', b) for the P% probability of occurrence are obtained based on the shift of the regression line to the desired value of P%.

This principle is schematically depicted in Figure 1. The material constants (σf', b) with P% ranging from 1% to 99% are obtained from the set of experimental points (σai, 2Nfi)i=1n for the fatigue–life curve in equation (2). Based on the methodology, the value of the fatigue strength coefficient σf' is a function of P%; the value of b remains unchanged for all values of probability. For fixed values of the stresses, the scatter of the lifetimes may be greater as the stress level is made smaller as in the figure aside. The assumption for ‘b’ constant may cause the confidence interval of estimation of lifetime being smaller at the low stress levels. If the difference of the scatters of lifetimes at different stress levels is large, the estimation for P% lifetime would exist a certain level of error. However, the 50% lifetime is not affected. The accurate values of ‘b’ for various stress levels under the same P% may need further to be studied in future. Here, parameter ‘b’ assumed as constant is to simplify the model of life estimation.

When utilizing the set of fatigue life experimental points to determine the regression line in accordance with the probabilistic form, the stress amplitude σa must be considered as an independent variable and the number of cycles to failure as a dependent variable. Therefore, it is necessary to perform linear regression in the coordinate system (2Nf)=f(σa). The regression line equation can be expressed as (3)log(2Nf)=-1blogσf'+1blogσa. Statistical evaluation of the set of n experimental points (σai,2Nfi)i=1n leads to the form (4)log(2Nf)=A0+B0logσa. The evaluated values of constants A0, B0 stands for the material at 50% probability of occurrence for (σai,2Nfi)i=1n The parameters of fatigue strength would be (5)A0=-1blogσf'⇒σf'=10-bA0,B0=1b⇒b=1Bo

The equation of the regression line that was shifted is as follows (6)log(2Nf)=A0±d(P%)sN+B0logσa, where d(P%) is the constant expressing the regression line shift (in multiples of the sN standard deviation) to the required value of P%. For P = 50%, the value d(50%) = 0. The signs (−) and (+) are valid for determination of the lower and upper interval limits, respectively, of the confidence interval.

For the set of n experimental points (σai,2Nfi)i=1n, the sN is given by the following relation (7)sN=∑i=1nYi2-A0∑i=1nYi-B0∑i=1nXiYin-2, where Y = log(2Nf), X = logσa, and the constants A0, B0 are the regression line parameters in equation (4). It follows the above-noted assumptions that the material constant b will remain unchanged for all values of P%. The value of σf' for P% is obtained using the evaluated constant A0 and the relevant value of the d(P%) constant. Let us set (8)A0±d(P%)sN=A1 The value of constant A1 with respect to equation (5) would be (9)A1=-1blogσf(P%)'. The value of the fatigue strength coefficient for P% would be (10)σf'=10-bA1=10-b(A0±d(P%)sN)

Using the same procedure, it is possible to obtain the set of material constants pertaining to Manson–Coffin’s curve.20 Let us also note that the assumption of a log-normal distribution of fatigue life, used in our model, is a widely accepted practice.

sec.title: Test specifications of DIs
sec.p: The parameters of the fatigue–life curve are evaluated through the regression analysis method based on the simulated and experimental data. For use in pre-manufactured prosthetic components, International standard ISO 1480121 had specified a scheme for signal post DIs.

sec.title: Testing scheme
sec.p:
Testing should be carried out for the worst-case conditions within the recommended use for the part of the DI system available in various dimensions and/or configurations. Figure 2 shows a schematic representation of the testing setup for DIs. The numbers (1–6) in Figure 2 indicate the loading device, the nominal bone level, the connecting part, the hemispherical loading member, the dental implant body and the specimen holder, respectively. The loading force (F) of the testing machine shall be applied so that no lateral constraints occur and the loading center is well-defined, so that the moment y can be measured or calculated. Figure 2.
Schematic of the test set-up for DIs.
DIs: dental implants.

The loading force is applied to the hemispherical loading surface by a loading device with the planar surface normal to the loading direction of the machine. The loading device is unconstrained in the transverse direction, so as to not reduce the magnitude of the applied bending moment. The hemispherical loading surface and the surface of the loading device are examined visually after each test to ensure that permanent deformation has not occurred. For a DI body and/or connecting part that locks rotational symmetry around either the central longitudinal axis of the implant body or the axis of nominal prosthetic loading, the loading geometry is selected so as to test for the worst case compatible with the intended use of the implant.

The bone-anchoring part of the specimen is fixed in a rigid clamping device. If an embedding material is used, it should have a module of elasticity higher than 3 GPa. The geometry of the clamping device is such that the testing geometry is achieved. The clamping device is designed so as not to deform the test specimen. The dimensions of the loading member are chosen to define a distance of l = 11±0.5 mm from the center of the hemisphere to the clamping plane. The moment arm y is defined as l × sin 30° for the standard configuration. As a result, the bending moment M is expressed as M = y × F.

sec.title: Loading process
sec.p: The fatigue testing is carried with a unidirectional load. The load varies sinusoidally between a normal peak value and 10% of that value. The loading frequency should exceed 15 Hz. The general principles for fatigue testing have been described in ISO 1099. The data for a load–cycle diagram for a series of loads are generated until a lower limit (maximum endured load) is reached at which at least three specimens survive and none falls in the specified number of cycles. The measured points in a load–cycle diagram are plotted. For testing conducted at a frequency ≥2 Hz testing shall be conducted to 5 × 106 cycles.

A proper starting load is 80% of the load to failure in a static test performance using the same test geometry. Subsequent tests are typically performed at lower loads resulting in a fatigue curve. At least two and preferably three specimens are tested for at least four loads each. The next step is to identify the critical failure point and the location of failure initiation. Failure is defined as the yielding or permanent deformation of the material, the loosing of the implant assembly or the fracturing of any component. The load cycle curve is drawn to show the maximum load at which the DI system withstands 5 × 106 cycles. Every specimen (at least three) resting at the maximum load endurance should reach the specified number of cycles with no failures. The fatigue properties of the test objects are determined by testing a number of specimens at different values of the peak load.

sec.title: Failure analysis of DIs
sec.p: DIs must undergo a dynamic fatigue testing for being deemed commercially viable in the market. To perform preliminary investigation of lifetime before testing, computer simulation analysis is performed to picture out the stress distributions and the fatigue life.

sec.title: Stress analysis
sec.p:
The DIs are primarily comprised of two parts, the fixture and the abutment. The fixture is screwed into the dental bone to sustain and fix the abutment. The abutment is used to support the artificial dental. The CAD models of DIs are constructed according to the geometric shape and the dimensions of the DIs offered by a dental clinic (Figure 3). The ANSYS software is utilized in analyzing the deformation, stress and fatigue life of the DIs. The CAD models of analyzing including the base and the hemisphere cup, and the settings in testing are shown in Figure 4. The strengths of the components including elastic module (E), yielding strength (σy) and ultimate strength (σu) are set according to the physical properties of the materials. In this example, the hemisphere cup is designed with structural steel where the material strengths {E, σy, σu} are {2 × 105, 250, 460} MPa, respectively, the abutment and the fixture made with pure titanium being {1.24 × 105, 657, 762} MPa, and the holder designed with polyethylene being {4.4 × 103, 75, 100} MPa. Figure 3.
Geometric shapes of a DI.
DI: dental implant.
Figure 4.
(a) Combination diagram of DIs for testing; (b) testing loads.
DIs: dental implants.

The contact types between these components in analyzing are set to no separation. The meshes of these components are automatically generated by the system. According to the study in Rismanchian et al.,22 the mean maximum bite force for the edentulous patients with mandibular implant-supported overdentures is 12.22 ± 27 kgf. Here, the loading for stress analysis is set to 500 N which is a rough value of the maximum load. The analysis results of the total deformation of the structure and the von Mises stress for these components each are shown in Figure 5. The total deformation of the structure at the load is 0.672 mm, and the maximum stress of the structure is 1061.5 MPa, which is occurring at the neck of the screw of the abutment. The analyzed results show that the abutment would fail prior to the fixture. Therefore, the abutment is regarded as the key component of the DIs and the fatigue life is further analyzed. The life evaluation is performed using the fatigue model in ANSYS software. Figure 5.
(a) Total deformation of a system; (b) stresses on the abutment; (b) stresses on the fixture; and (d) stresses on the holder.

sec.title: Fatigue analysis
sec.p:
There are two variables which need to be set while implementing fatigue life analysis. One is to determine the load type. The other is to set the analysis models for which consider the effects of mean stress to lifetime.23 According to the tested specifications, the loads would vary between the maximum load and 10% of the maximum load. The load setting and the fracture line subjected to Goodman models, for example, are shown in Figure 6. Here, the maximum load is set to 547 N, which is obtained by the static test using the same test geometry. The fatigue limits of the abutment and the fixture made by pure Titanium are set to 350 MPa subjected to a life of 107 cycles, which is obtained from the atlas of the fatigue curves.24 The estimated lifetimes of the abutment given under different fracture models are compared with the test data obtained at 80% of the maximum load. The simulation results show that the life estimation produced by the Gerber model is one that the most closed to the lifetimes of the experimental data. Therefore, the fatigue life under the other loads are estimated using the Gerber model. In this example, the maximum equivalent stress at loads between 43.8 N and 438 N (80% of the maximum load) was 621.7 MPa, and the corresponding fatigue life at the loading is 2656.1 cycles (Figure 7). The safety factor of fatigue failure related to 5 × 106 cycles was 0.7389. The sensitivity of the fatigue life related to loading varying from 80% to 120% of the load 438 N is shown in Figure 8. The results show the estimated lifetime at 80% of the load 438 N, i.e. 350 N being 64% of the maximum load, for example, would be 9.65 × 104 cycles. The analyzed results for different scales (percentages) of the maximum load in this example are listed in Table 1. Based on the simulated results, the lowest maximum load to satisfy the expected life (5 × 106 cycles) would be 323 N (59% of the maximum load). Figure 6.
The loading setting and the fracture models: (a) constant amplitude load ratio; (b) mean stress correction theory.
Figure 7.
(a) The equivalent stresses and (b) lifetimes of the abutment at 80% of the maximum load.
Figure 8.
Sensitivity of the fatigue life to the loading scale.
Table 1.
The analyzed results of fatigue life at various scales of the maximum load 547 N.
Scales 80% 75% 73% 70% 64% 60% 59% 50%
Fmax 438 410 397 383 350 328 323 274
N 2.7E + 03 1.0E + 04 1.8E + 04 3.1E + 04 9.7E + 04 2.6E + 06 5.4E + 06 1.0E + 07

sec.title: Fatigue life estimation
sec.p: The probabilistic form of fatigue life can be decided by applying distribution identification to the experimental data. In this study, the experimental data at high stress levels are acquired by fatigue testing. The experimental data were combined with the simulation results to construct the model of fatigue life estimation.

sec.title: Fatigue testing
sec.p: The maximum load of testing is determined by the static test. In the static test, a preload of 5 N is applied first, then a compressive load is applied at a rate of 1 mm/min on the loading cap until the implant failure or until the force decreases to less than 20% of the maximum load. The data are generated for the load versus displacement diagram. The maximum force of the static test is determined from the load versus displacement diagram. The maximum load (547 N) is the mean of the test values of four samples.

The fatigue tests are then carried according to the maximum load of the static test. The cyclic loading is set to 80% of the maximum load. The R value (Fmax/Fmin) is set to 10. The test frequency is 10 Hz. An implant which endures over 5 × 106 cycles of load can be regarded as having passed. Fracturing of any component or yielding of the material is regarded as failure. Yielding of the material is defined as when the applied load at the point of intersection between the stress–strain curve and the slope of the offset displacement is 0.2% the strain. The yielding displacement is 0.525 mm, as calculated from the load–displacement diagram for the static test. Figure 9 shows the failure of a DI specimen. It is broken at the neck of the screw. Figure 9.
Failure of a DI specimen.
DI: dental implant.
In this example, the fatigue lifetimes at the cyclic loads (80% of the maximum load) for 3 specimens are N={834,2255,4522}.
Generally, the magnitude of the scatter of cyclic properties is an important parameter in fatigue-reliability evaluation because it affects the shape of the distribution function.

sec.title: Reliability analysis
sec.p:
The fatigue life model of DIs is formulated by the Basquin equation. The parameters are determined using a linear regression method based on the combined data acquired by fatigue testing and computer simulation. The estimated resulting trend of the fatigue life with respect to loads is shown in Figure 10. The fatigue life model would be log(2Nf)=57.33-20.31log(Fmax). Figure 10.
Fatigue life curve of the DI.
DI: dental implant.

The correlated coefficient for the life curve and the data is R2 = 0.932. The results indicate that the fatigue life model possesses a high correlation with the lifetime data which is suitable to be used in estimating the fatigue life of DIs. According to the results, the fatigue strength coefficient and the fatigue strength exponent can be obtained by equation (5). They are σf'=665 and b=-0.049. The estimated lifetimes for various maximum loads obtained based on this model are listed in Table 2. In particular, the maximum load for the expected lifetime of 5 × 106 cycles would be 301 N. The results show that the estimated value of the allowed maximum load for 5 × 106 cycles by the life estimation model is more conservative than the simulated value. Table 2.
The estimated lifetimes based on the fatigue life model.
Fmax 438 410 397 383 350 328 323 274
N 2.5E + 03 9.1E + 03 1.8E + 04 3.7E + 04 2.3E + 05 8.5E + 05 1.2E + 06 3.4E + 07

Moreover, the estimated values for 95% confidence intervals for σf' and b would be (81.8, 15657.2) and (−0.041, −0.062), respectively. Based on the estimated values of σf', The probabilistic lifetime of the DI at different P% of confidence intervals can then be estimated by equation (6). Here, the evaluated standard deviation for the fatigue life is calculated by equation (7) as slog(N) = 0.395.

Considering the variation of the materials, the fatigue life for each load can be regarded as lognormal distribution since it is extensively used in life analysis. Combining the estimated values of P = 50% lifetime and the standard deviation of estimation, the reliabilities of fatigue life at different loads can be further computed. The characteristic parameters for the lifetime for lognormal distribution are defined as (µY, σY). The parameters can be estimated by (11)μY=logμX-12σY2,σY2=log[(σXμX)2+1] where the parameters (µX, σX) are the mean and the standard deviation of lifetime for normal distribution. The standard deviation of fatigue life can be set to be σY = slog(N) as well as the mean representing the 50% lifetime as µY = log(N). As a result, the reliability of DIs under different loads can be evaluated by (12)R(t)=Φ(log(N)-μYσY). The evaluated results of reliability, for example, for loads at 80%, 70% and 60% of the maximum load are shown in Figure 11. The results are useful in risk assessments for DIs in use. Figure 11.
Reliability of the DI for different loads.
DI: dental implant.

Normally, the magnitude of the standard deviation of the DIs material’s cyclic properties greatly affects the fatigue reliability. Based on the proposed methodology, the maximum permissible value of load can be determined to ensure that the probability of the occurrence of premature fatigue failure occurrence will not exceed the allowable value.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Common problems for fatigue testing are the long time testing and large cost expenditure, especially for low stress fatigue testing. An effective approach to reduce the testing time and cost is to replace the experimental data with computer simulation results. This article proposes a fatigue life estimation method based on the combined information of CAE analysis and fatigue testing for evaluating the lifetime of DIs. The probabilistic form of life estimation is reported to provide an estimation of lifetime confidence intervals. The fatigue life of DIs is analyzed using the ANSYS software. The stress distributions under the static loads are first investigated to establish the key part of the DIs. The analyzed results show that the maximum stress occurs at the abutment. The fatigue life of the abutment is then simulated based on the specifications of the dynamic fatigue testing. The estimated lifetimes at 80% of the maximum load subjected to three fracture models are compared with the experimental data obtained by fatigue testing. The results show that the Gerber model is the best one in estimating the fatigue life for DIs. As a result, the corresponding information including the equivalent stresses, safety factors and the sensitivity of fatigue life to loads are also investigated based on this model. The lifetime estimation model is constructed using linear regression method based on the combined information of computer simulation and dynamic fatigue testing. The properties of the study are to perform lifetime estimation based on a probabilistic form and a small amount of test data. Furthermore, the method of reliability evaluation of fatigue life is proposed in cooperation with the estimation values of mean and standard deviation. The results may be useful in risk assessment for usage of DIs.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The work was supported by a grant from the National Science Council under contract No. NSC 100-2221-E-237-001.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors are grateful to Dr YK Lu and JB Lu, Ti-Ho Healthcare Technology Co., LTD. for providing the design drawing of DIs and the test data. The authors would like to express their appreciation to the reviewers for their valuable suggestions.
